175. Groshong, Margaret Ann (Mrs. Willis R).
Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and will it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name: Mrs. W.R. Armstrong
Address: Qu'Appelle, Sask.
Birthplace: Port Hope, Ontario

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? Homestead in N.A. District
Where had you been living before that? Russell, N.B.
For how many people did you prepare meals? Three
How far was it to your nearest store? 3 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Tea, coffee, sugar, rice, rolled oats, grits, corn meal, beans, syrup etc.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Redman Flour
King Brand, Harold
In what quantities did you buy it? One hundred pound sacks
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.50 per hundred
How much did you use Graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? 32 miles
What year? 1906
That was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 2 cents
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes
Whole wheat? Yes
Farina?
Grits?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? In an ordinary feed grinder
1. What year did you start housekeeping? 1916

2. How many people did you marry before that? Russell & Ethel

3. How far are we to your nearest store? 3 miles

4. How often would a visit be made to the store? Once a week

5. What groceries did you usually buy in those early days?

   - Tea, coffee, sugar, flour, rice, salt, beans, syrup, etc.

6. What brand of cake flour did you use in the early days?

   - King Arnold's

7. How much did you pay per hundred pounds of cake flour?

   - $3.25

8. Did you make your own bread for parties?

   - Yes

9. Did you grind your own wheat for flour?

   - Yes
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lbs.
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $5.00.
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Royal Crown.
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 lb.
At what price? $0.75.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From a cow.
Did you purchase eggs? No.
What was the price of butter? $2.00.
Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.
Did you make butter? Yes.
What kind of cheese? Cheddar.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef, pork, chicken, turkey.
How did you get fresh meat? Butchered it.
How often did you get fresh meat?
How did you preserve meat? Salt method.
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes, in later years.
If so what year was it organized? 1915.
Did you use game? Yes.
What kinds? Deer.
For how long? In season.
What part did fish play in the family diet? Had fish occasionally.
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh, cured, canned.
Kinds? Salmon, cod, pike.

What kind of tea did you buy? Blue Ribbon at what price? $3.50 per lb.

Price? $2.50. What other beverages were used? Coffee.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? $5.00 per bushel.

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes.

If not, where from?

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes 1907, Cabbages 1907, Carrots 1907, Onions 1907.

Turnips 1907, Beets 1907.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 5 lbs. lot.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Bulk or box.

What weight? 10 lbs. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Yes.

Bulk. What was the price of prunes? $9.00 per lb.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Peas? Yes. Corn? Yes. Beans? Yes. Saskatoons? No.

Other foods?

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1908.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1908.

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1910.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes.

To what extent? The years and plenty.

Did you make your own vinegar? No.
6. What kind of tea did you buy? Black tea
   Price: $3.50 per lb.

7. What was the price of potatoes per lb.? You paid $1.00 per lb.

8. In what quantities did you buy potatoes? 5 lbs.

9. How did you buy potatoes? (in bulk or by the box) Bulk

10. What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter? 1942

11. What other dried fruits did you use in the substitute days? Apples, pears, apricots, peaches, tomatoes, raisins, currants or others?

12. Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes

13. To what extent? The majority of my family

13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? ... Both ...
If you made your own, did you use lye? ... Yes ... wood ash? ... No ...
What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? ... Comfort & Reynolds ...

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? ... Buffalo chips ...
Where did you get your fuel? ... Purchased it ...
... Charcoal from Eastover Mines ...

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Propane gas stove about 1946

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) ...............................................................

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) ... 1908 ...

By whom was your first cook stove made? ... Clyde ... made in South ...

What year was it purchased? ... 1924 ... Price? ... $32.00 ...

Aluminum? ... 1914 ...
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Wrappings changed from paper bags & cardboard boxes & elephant proofs.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

June 8, 1924.
Me & daughter Mrs. & two children.
Age 24 - 4 & little girl 3 yrs.
I served Turkey Dressing Potatoes gravy & pudding & hot Creme.
Pumpkin & white bread & tea.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Have more prepared breakfast foods than fruit today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

In 1930 we began to use more prepared foods than formerly.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

We traded Eggs & Butter for Groceries and Dried Vegetables in exchange for Groceries also took our wheat to the Mill to get our own flour - drove to the mines with team for our coal 33 mile sometimes took two days - used lanterns then for light also kerosene oil lamps & gallon of coal oil did us the 1st winter of 1906 - Coal then was $15.00 a ton at the mine, we used 6 ton of coal 1st winter just used the cook stove -

Mrs W.R. Grosberg -
Cunning -
Sask

Nov. 26th 1950
